ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to apply sociological lenses to my life and look at things from a bigger picture perspective
Many sociological concepts and how they relate to sport.
Broader knowledge of sociological concepts regarding race, gender, socioeconomics, while tied into sports and current events.

Unfortunately, I really didn't feel like I learned much in this class. A lot of the course was very redundant and circular with extensive time each lecture dedicated to small group discussions which quickly devolved into nothing more than talking about non class related things. I think lectures should actually be lectures. Might have been better as a seminar.
I learned about the history of some sports and some sociological concepts in sports.
Amazing knowledge of the politics around sports

Sports and Society is a great into sociology class. We covered a lot of basic sociological topics, and I feel like sport is a more interesting vehicle than most to do that with. Maybe my frustration is with the field of sociology and not with this specific course, but I felt like we never really reached conclusions about the questions that we posed.
Looking at sport through the lens of sociology and how people interact with sports
Learned about history/context of some sports and some knowledge of sociology
Mostly helped build knowledge about sociological theories and how to apply them to the sporting world.
thinking about sports through a sociological lens and exploring various themes and institutions that are prevalent in sports
Its an introduction to sports as a sociological concept. This class teaches you to critically analyze the world around you and makes you look at sports differently.

In this course you learn all about how sports and the athletic life in different settings and communities impact and shape our society. There is a lot more of a connection than you initially realize. Throughout the course you learn how to conduct a sociological analysis and make new connections between sports and our society.

The class allowed me to explore the different ways in sport reflects and changes the society in which it exists. On top of this, the wide range of sports discussed in this class exposed me to new sports which I knew little or nothing about prior to taking this course. As for tangible skills, the peer writing assignments helped improve my collaboration skills as I had to cooperate with my writing partner to ensure that our assignments were completed in a timely manner.

Really interesting insight into sports as a sociological institution and how we interact with the world of sports. Discussed placemaking, consumerism, sports as a place of social change, and whether or not sports were inherently good. Forced me to reconsider a lot of inherent biases I had coming into the course and to consider why sports historically haven't been taken that seriously as a field of academic research.

I learned a great deal about sports, not on the surface level but more in depth on how ingrained and critical it is to societies foundation. It was a class where it broadened my perspective on athletes, the way I view sports as an athlete, and high elite level sports.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Engaging, allows for various forms of participation, enjoyable to attend
I loved the course! Overall, it was amazing!

I loved the use of Perusall. It allowed us to engage with the course and participate without having to raise our hand in class which can be anxiety-inducing. I think the grading was a little harsh honestly and not always clear with feedback which was a little frustrating given the rest of the class experience was very laid back.
Should be a seminar or completely restructured.
The course is very repetitive, the grading is harsh and not at all helpful in improving your knowledge or abilities, the assignments are unnecessary, and the TA wasn't great.
Just so much fun! Interactive! Organized!

Strengths - interesting readings, engaged discussions
Weaknesses - unclear feedback on writings, no engagement with TF
It was a very good survey course that covered many aspects of how people interact with sports and the impact of sports on everyday society.

The biggest strength of the course was that the students in it had a broad array of experiences with sports. The biggest weaknesses were the grading and the organization. We were expected to use lots of sociological terms but it didn't feel like we'd ever actually learned their definitions. The grading of the course was also brutal for seemingly no reason. The TA and Professor had very different standards, and its seemed like grades were kind of random which made things stressful. The correspondence assignments were fine, but the written ones were tons more work than the audio ones and were graded much more harshly. There wasn't much room to grow, and it seemed like we'd get marked down for not mentioning random things outside the scope of assignments. The class organization was also a weakness. The professor didn't seem to know whether he wanted it to be a lecture or a seminar, and the in-between size was rough.

strengths: interesting material and discussions; fun readings
weakness: while I loved how there wasn't too much emphasis on the intricacies of a given theory (more of a brief overview), I felt like Prof. Manning wanted more discussion of theory in our papers so if that's the case I would like to see more lecture slides giving definitions of theories

This course was attempting to be a seminar but there were way to many people to have discussions in class. For many people, this was their first time taking a sociology class, and I think there wasnt enough time spent learning the sociological concepts that we were supposed to reference in our writing.

Strengths- Even though the class is a lecture, the class is discussion based, and Prof. Manning does a great job getting everyone involved. The class is super well organized and Prof. Manning is a gifted lecturer.

The strengths of this course include the wide range of sports which are discussed and their connections to sociology. Furthermore, the open-nature of the midterm and final writing assignments allowed students to write about topics for which they felt most passionate. This course could be improved by going into a bit more depth concerning the sociological theories which underly analyzation lenses used in the course.

Great organizational structure and really enjoyed the correspondence assignments. Difficult for shy people to get good in-class participation grade, however, as speaking in front of 40 people can be daunting.

Strengths: the layout was straightforward and organized easy to follow, professor was great, material was interesting, class was engaging and fun
Weaknesses: sometimes it felt there was too much reading material there are times where I feel that we werent able to cover all of the assigned work, the class slides could contain more sociological terms and recaps of all of the important terminology at least once to refresh for final projects, it would help to have more and perhaps earlier check ins during the larger projects.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Super enjoyable and you don't have to be an athlete to engage
Yes! It was an extremely engaging course with something for everyone!
It depends. I think if you are looking for an easy A just because you think sports aren't a serious sociological concept than no. I think if you really wanna dive deep into sociology then yes.

I would not recommend you take this class. It is one of the only sports related classes which is why people take it but I promise you it is not worth it and I recommend you find another class about sports.
Yes
Its a brilliant space where you can talk about your passions of sports in an educational way. You can explore any topics!
If you have spare credit Ds then yes

I would recommend this course to another student who is looking to fill their schedule, but I would not build my schedule around this class. I liked class because I participated in it, but that participation was not reflected in how the TF graded responses. I wonder if the class is better suited as a seminar.

I would highly recommend, even if you're someone who is just interested in sports from a sociological perspective, you don't have to know a lot about them or play a sport yourself to get a lot out of this class

I would not recommend this class. The grading was unnecessarily harsh and it ended up hindering my engagement. The class structure was also strange, trying to be a "leminar" where we spent much of the class just talking to neighbors every time and reporting back. I ultimately ended up dreading class time, which was really sad because I took this to be a fun class. If it's run in the same style as it was this time, I wouldn't recommend it.
yes
It is a good course to take if you want to learn about sports through a sociological lens. If you want to learn sociology, this isnt the right course for you.
100%. This might be my favorite class Ive taken at Yale.
Yes this is a great course if you're looking to take a sociology class and learn more about how sports are more important than we initially think.

Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone. Whether you are an avid sports fan, confused about why people care so much about sports, or just have a general interest in sociology, there is something in this course for everyone.

Yes I found it very insightful and truly was a good refuge class that wasnt, in my case, just hardcore stem classes. It was a class I enjoyed to attend and learn about. It was a great way to expand my mindset about sports.
